Description: Body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery kylix; interior glazed black (only traces remaining); exterior: black-figure decoration: bird or siren standing to left (part of wing with added red, body and legs); below, wide black band between sets of three narrow bands; further glazed area below.
Curator's comments: The sherd comes from an open vessel, probably a cup (not a round aryballos as given by Venit and Möller). For the shape and the winged creature, compare the cup attributed to the Medallion Painter, Boston 12.422 (Amyx 1988, 195, pl. 76; Boardman 1998, 197, figs 393,1,2). The sherd probably belongs with British Museum 1924,1201.1190.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 67, no. A53)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 221, no. 2)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.095) (Phase 1)
